results.notes:
Original Herbarium Label: Meripilus giganteus (Pers.) P. Karst.
Growing on roots of Aesculus hippocastanum on watered street boulevard
The same site as 2016 observation:
http://mushroomobserver.org/255011
That one was found by James Holkko & Juliet Pendray
Dr. Jim Ginns draw our attention (2017/07/16) to this article:
Larsen, M.J. & Frances F. Lombard. 1988. The status of Meripilus giganteus (Aphyllophorales, Polyporaceae) in North America. Mycologia 80: 612-621.
This particular specimen has 3-5 pores per 1 mm. This and the pilear surface being “finely fibrillose with minute squamules” would suggest that this is an introduced European species, Meripilus giganteus and not the North American native Meripilus sumstinei (Murrill) M.J. Larsen & Lombard.

2017-07-21: Duplicate sent for ID to Dr. Jim Ginns

results.notes:
A NJMA Foray collection.
A group of several specimens growing in mixed deciduous woods dominated by oak. Doesn’t look like badiceps or indecisus to my eye. Might be ferrugineus, as KOH on cut flesh gave a pale yellow reaction (a feature listed in NAB, but not in BENA), but the stipe coloration (a wide white band at apex with a gradient of brown below) doesn’t add much confidence to this ID. The cut flesh started staining pinkish-brown within a few seconds, reaching full intensity withing a couple of minutes; it tasted mild with a bit of an astringent note early on. KOH on cap = mahogany-red; NH4OH = mahogany brown, paler than KOH.
While badiceps is usually a pretty distinct taxon, owing to its color of the cap and stipe, ferrugineus in my experience is a morphologically variable entity, leading me to think it could be a species cluster.
I didn’t save this collection even though the caps were largely free of insect activity; the stipes were thoroughly eaten by fly larvae.

A NJMA Foray collection (I did’t collect it); preserved for RET.
Growing in mixed deciduous woods dominated by oaks, beech, hickory and maples. This entity is characterized by a disproportionately long stipe (16.5 cm) relative to the width of cap (>3.0<3.5 cm). The cap is dark caramel-brown to medium chocolate brown, lacking yellowish tones. The white stipe had some brownish stains; not sure if these are natural or due to color transfer from other mushrooms. The white volva is a thin tubular sock of ~4 cm in length; it’s wrapped so tightly around the stipe, rendering it almost invisible.

Half of this collection was sent to Dr. B.T.M. Dentinger at UMNH in March 2018.

DNA Sequencing Results and Discussion:
> A clean and contiguous nrLSU sequence consisting of the first 993 bps (through to and including the LR5 primer) was obtained from this material by Dr. Kudzma. There is a single ambiguous character, a “Y”.
Two BLASTn searches were performed — the full sequence and the first 976 bps (sans the LR5 primer). The corresponding phylograms consisting of the first 32 hits were built in GenBank and posted to this observation. Removal of the LR5 primer from the sequence makes a difference in the overall hit profile topology; however, the “Alloboletus” clade of porcini sensu lato stands out in both trees.
As can been seem from the GB data, the only [almost] matching sequence (2 bps of, including the ambiguity; 99.8% similarity) is with that of Tylopilus rhoadsiae/AY612836. That collection was obviously misidentified, as it clades in “Alloboletus”, and there are no other Tylopilus hits in the 993 bps cladogram. It’s almost certain that a faded, bleached out B. separans was mistaken for T. rhoadsiae. Unfortunately, the collection location of that voucher is unknown.
The TX collection DPL2704/KF030329 identified as B. separans (DPL = David P. Lewis) is only only 97% similar to MO282660. It’s obviously a closely related taxon and a morphological doppelganger of the true northeastern B. separans described by Peck from NY, which this observation (282660) IMO represents. A BLAST search of DPL2704/KFO30329 gave a perfect match – X. separans BD243/EU232000 (BD = B.T.M. Dentinger) collected in NC. The reason EU232000 didn’t show up in the BLASTn searches of this observation is because it’s a much shorter sequence (837 bps); this annoying GB quirk has already been discussed by me elsewhere. Incidentally, the LSU traces derived from separans-like obs 254730 (NC) and obs 280000 (TX) are identical to KF030329/EU232000.
> A clean and contiguous TEF-1-alpha sequence of 683 bps was obtained from this material. The sequence begins from the EF1-983F primer; the last 70 bases follow the EF1-1567R primer. There are no ambiguous characters, this is a single haplotype.
As expected, a BLASTn search of the 613 fragment (the region between and including the aforementioned primers) gave a hit profile consistent with this taxon being part of “Alloboletus”. Interestingly, however, there were no matches, and the greatest similarity was only 96.5% to B. violaceofuscus. This sequence is only 95.9% similar to KF030431 associated with the familiar “B. separans”/DPL2704 from TX.
A phylogram was assembled in GenBank using the top 35 hits (sorted by % identity) and posted to this observation. “Alloboletus” and “Boletus s.s.” appear as well-defined sister clades, as they should.
> Discussion: Boletus separans is an iconic northeastern taxon originally described by Peck from New York state. The bolete in this post is presumed to be it based on the gross morphology and biogeography (NJ is part of the Northeast, naturally). However, analysis of the LSU and TEF-1 sequences reveals that there are no matching data in GenBank, at least under this name (vide supra). Instead, GB accessions of what was identified as B. separans Peck from southeastern/southern USA (NC and TX) represent a phylogenetically distinct but related taxon in “Alloboletus”. This development is further complicated by the potential existence of another legitimately published species – Boletus pseudoseparans – originally described from NC by Grand & Smith (1971) following their re-examination of collections by Coker and Beers. However, it’s been generally understood that pseudoseparans is likely conspecific with B. separans Peck, as Smith’s concept of separans appears to be different from that of Peck, though this claim has never been supported/proven by molecular means. 2, 3
More collections from different parts of the USA and genetic analyses are needed to get a full picture of the B. separans species complex. At this point in time, preliminary evidence suggests that Peck’s B. separans is mostly restricted to northeastern USA and its southern range probably goes as far as VA or NC (where it overlaps with the northern range of the “southern impostor” represented by GenBank’s DPL2704/BD243 and obs 254730 & obs 280000) and its western distribution is presumed to extend as far as Illinois.
References:
1 ≈†utara, J.: Czech Mycology 2014, term 66(2), pp. 157‚Äì170
2 Both, E.E.: The Boletes of North America, a Compendium , p. 253
3 Mushroom Expert: http://www.mushroomexpert.com/boletus_separans.html

DNA Sequencing Results (last updated 14-Nov-18):
> A clean and contiguous 1007 nrDNA sequence was obtained from this collection and uploaded to this observation. It consists of the last 639 characters of nrITS, followed by the first 368 characters of the nrLSU region. There are no ambiguous characters present, this is a single haplotype.
> A BLASTn search of the nrITS sequence only yielded the following relevant results (sorted by % identity):
EU231958: Boletus variipes BD245 collected by B.T.M. Dentinger under beech in Duke Forest in North Carolina = 625/625 = 100% match
EU231957: Boletus aff. variipes var. fagicola REH8545 collected by R.E. Halling et al. under oak and pine in Belize in 2003 = 619/620 = 99.8% match
EU231956: Boletus aff. variipes var. fagicola REH8527 collected by R.E. Halling et al. under oak in Belize in 2003 = 619/621 = 99.7% match
JN020994: Boletus variipes BD369 collected by B.T.M. Dentinger under beech in Costa Rica = 622/627 = 99.2% match1
EU231955: Boletus aff. variipes var. fagicola REH7756 collected by R.E. Halling et al. under oak in Costa Rica in 1997 = 611/622 = 98.2% match2
> A further inspection of the nrITS BLASTn results led to the discovery of a second cluster of relevant accessions labeled as B. variipes by their respective authors. Though only 93-94% similar to the ITS of MO282673, notably this group of accessions includes the nrITS sequence of A.H. Smith‚Äôs B. variipes var. fagicola HOLOTYPE (sorted by % identity):
KY826165: Boletales sp. voucher RL010, collected by R. Lebeuf in SE Canada3
KY826012: Boletales sp. voucher B0962, collected by Y. Lamoureux in SE Canada
KY826107: Boletales sp. voucher B3041, collected by Y. Lamoureux in SE Canada4
KY825988: Boletales sp. voucher B0246, collected by Y. Lamoureux in SE Canada5
EU231961: Boletus variipes BD201, collected by B.T.M. Dentinger under oak in Chestnut Ridge Park, south of Buffalo, NY
EU231963: Boletus variipes BD190, collected by B.T.M. Dentinger under hemlock, oak and beech in Allegheny National Forest, PA
EU231962/NR_119673: Boletus variipes var. fagicola AHS75914/MICH 10063 HOLOTYPE, collected in 1968 by A.H. Smith in beech-maple-aspen woods near Wolverine, MI
Discussion of Results:
Analysis of the above sequencing data (see the recently uploaded GenBank-generated phylogram consisting of the assorted BLASTn hits) coupled with a thorough literature research suggest this NJ collection belongs in the ‚ÄúVariipes-clade‚Äù of the porcini s. str. lineage of Boletus s. str./Boletus sect. Boletus by virtue of being conspecific with EU231958.6,7
As per Dentinger et al. (2010) and Feng et al. (2012), the ‚ÄúVariipes-clade‚Äù currently consists of three entities (at the phylogenetic resolution of nrITS):
1) The [ostensibly] undescribed taxon (or perhaps species group) represented by a large number of vouchers from a wide geographical range (Connecticut, USA, south to Florida and into Belize & Costa Rica)
2) Boletus variipes Peck/Smith & Thiers (from northeastern USA)
3) Boletus hiratsukae (endemic to Japan)

References:
1 This collection is called Boletus cf. variipes var. fagicola BD369 in Mol. Phylogenet. Evol. 2010, term 57, 1276-1292. A photograph of it can be visualized in the above publication on p. 1278.
2 Of the 11 mismatching positions, 5 are gaps and 5 are ambiguous characters of ‚ÄúN‚Äù-type, which can represent any of the 4 nucleotides. Since it‚Äôs possible that at least some of these are editing errors, the actual % identity could be higher. A photograph of this collection can be visualized at http://sweetgum.nybg.org/....
3 Ren√©e Lebeuf‚Äôs pictures of this collection are uploaded to this observation.
4 Original identification by Yves Lamoureux as B. variipes Peck. A photo of this collection can be found at https://www.flickr.com/... (courtesy of Ren√©e Lebeuf).
5 Original identification by Yves Lamoureux as B. atkinsonii Peck. A photo of this collection can be found at https://www.flickr.com/... (courtesy of Ren√©e Lebeuf).
6 Dentinger et al.: ‚ÄúMolecular Phylogenetics of Porcini Mushrooms (Boletus section Boletus); Mol. Phylogenet. Evol. 2010, term 57, pp.1276-1292.
7 Feng et al.: ‚ÄúDNA Sequence Analyses Reveal Abundant Diversity, Endemism and Evidence for Asian Origin of the Porcini Mushrooms‚Äù; PLoS One 2012, term 7(5), e37567.

Two fruiting bodies growing in grass/moss in the vicinity of old oaks. This collection was found only about 15-20 yards away from another Leccinellum species, obs 282666.
Large Basidocarp Dimensions: overall height = ~11 cm; cap = 7.8 cm wide, 2.2 cm thick in the middle; tubes = 1.1 cm long; stipe = 8.5 cm long; 2.5 cm wide at apex, ~2 cm wide near base (tapering downward).
Small Basidocarp Dimensions: overall height = ~8.5 cm; cap = 4.1 cm wide, 1 cm thick in the middle; tubes = 1.1 cm long; stipe = 7.5 cm long (measured in sections); 1 cm wide at apex 1.5 cm wide in the middle, 1.1 cm wide near base (ventricose).
Discussion: This could be the same taxon as that of obs 244590, as the cap of the young specimen here looks essentially identical – a deeply pitted/pockmarked dark brown (almost black) surface with a violet sheen and tawny/orangish areas here and there. In age the pits get shallower and the surface looks just wrinkled/corrugated and cracked, and the pileipellis assumes a lighter shade of brown, especially on disk (similar to L. rugosiceps??). The pore surface is light yellow and bruises light brown. The stipes are whitish and covered with a vertical network light brown scabers that darken in age and upon handling to a darker shade of brown. The shape of stipe is ventricose in the young fb and tapering downward in old fb. The flesh is cream-colored, staining brownish-red or fulvous within 10-15 seconds in the cap and the upper half of stipe (same as in 244590: see http://mushroomobserver.org/...). The rubescens intensifies over a few minutes; following this, it changes to medium pigeon blue and then to brown in the cap and directly to brown in the stipe. The flesh of the exsiccatae is dark brown. Odor and taste not recorded. No chemical tests were performed.
The older fb dropped some spores. The spore print is very light and its color cannot be accurately ascertained.
Spore Measurements:
[20/1/1], mounted in Melzer’s and measured in side-view only (hilar appendage to the side):
L x W = 12.1 – 14.9 (-15.3) x (5.1-) 5.3 – 6.3 Œºm;
L’ x W‚Äô = 13.7 × 5.7 Œºm;
Q = 2.24 – 2.58; Q‚Äô = 2.39.
Straw-yellow to dingy-yellow and inamyloid in Melzer’s; equilateral and fusiform (spindle-shaped) with tapered ends in face-view (dorsal/ventral) and inequilateral (subfusiform) in side-view (dorsiventral), with a moderate to well-developed suprahilar plage.
Spore Data Comparison: Den Bakker and Noordeloos (Persoonia 2005, term 18(4), 511-587) give the following spore data for European collections of Leccinum crocipodium: “Spores (11.5-)12-15 × 5.0-6.5 Œºm, on average 13-14 × 5.5-6.0 Œºm, Q = 2.0-2.9, Qav = 2.3-2.4; fusiform with conical apex, often almost amygdaliform, with a light to distinct suprahilar depression, relatively thin-walled, pale brown in water”.
Bessettes’ NAB & BENA give the following information on the spores of American collections of Leccinum nigrescens = Leccinellum crocipodium (1) and Leccinum rugosiceps (2):
(1) 14-20 × 6-9 Œºm, fusiform, smooth, yellowish
(2) 15-21 × 5-6 Œºm, fusiform, smooth, pale brown

Spore Date Discussion: As can be seen from comparing these data, the spore parameters of 282883 are an almost perfect match to those of the European collections crocipodium in all respects! However, comparison of the spore shapes reveals that the spores of 282883 have a more tapered and narrower distal end, a more spindle-shaped face-view silhouette, and a more curvy side-view silhouette relative to the spore drawings in the European paper.
American collections of nigrescens/crocipodium feature much longer and wider spores, suggesting that it’s not conspecific with the European entity.
Furthermore, there are notable differences in their morphological descriptions.
Leccinum rugosiceps has much longer spores than 282883, so it can be excluded from consideration based on this evidence alone.

DNA Sequencing Results (posted on 19-May-2018):
> Originally, a TEF-1 sequence was requested; however, clean reads couldn’t be obtained and the ribosomal loci were explored instead.
> A clean and contiguous nrLSU sequence consisting of the first 981 bps was derived from this collection. A BLASTn search produced no perfect or even close matches, and the highest achieved similarity was only ~95.8% with Leccinellum crocipodium AY139694. A phylogram consisting only of hits in Leccinoideae (with B. separans as an outgroup) was build in GenBank and posted to this observation. As can be seen therein, Leccinellum is not a monophyletic clade, but this is not surprising considering that nrLSU is not the optimal locus for building reliable single-gene phylogenies.
> A nrITS sequence was also procured, but an assembled contiguous read was not possible due to issues with heterogeneity that are so typical for this locus. Only the forward (5’—>3’) read consisting of the last 19 bps of nrSSU followed by full ITS1, 5.8S and a large portion of ITS2 region (for a total of 802 bps is available at this time), but Dr. Kudzma is hopeful to get a clean, high quality sequence eventually. A BLASTn of this sequence fragment gave a close match (457/461) with MH234469 associated with my obs 244590. There is no doubt the two collections are conspecific, which is also supported by their close morphological semblance. It’s interesting that 3 out of 4 mismatching bases are a 3-base deletion in 282883 (Dr. K confirmed it’s very much real).

“Distinguishing characters: Aspergillus melleus colonies typically sporulate well and produce abundant white to yellow to brownish orange sclerotia. On DG18, colonies have a greyish green (1C4) colour in mycelial areas and an olive reverse. A similar olive reverse was observed in A. pallidofulvus, A. ochraceus, A. ostianus and A. roseoglobulosus. However, A. melleus lacks the dull red mycelia of A. roseoglobulosus on CYA, grows faster on CYA at 37 ¬∞C than A. ostianus (no growth to microcolonies), and grows faster than A. ochraceus (40‚Äì47 mm, 25‚Äì35 mm) on CYA at 30 and 33 ¬∞C. Compared to A. pallidofulvus, A. melleus has a more orange conidial colour on MEA, grows slower on MEA, DG18 and OA, and produces finely roughened conidia, which are smooth in A. pallidofulvus.”

results.notes:
A cluster of three young/immature but sizable fruiting bodies growing in an oak grove. A single specimen was collected and preserved.
There was some superficial bluing on the stipe due to handling, but neither the pores nor the yellow flesh both in stipe and cap blued. The stipe flesh was an alternating streaky scheme of darker & lighter shades of yellow, whereas the cap flesh of homogeneously/solid yellow and paler. The tube layer was only 1 mm thick, while the cap flesh was 1.5 cm thick in the middle. The odor of the intact mushroom was slightly earthy/pungent, but not unpleasant, and the odor of the cut flesh was fungal/mushroomy.
Chemical Tests (performed 7-8 hrs post collection): KOH = bright rusty brown to orangish-brown on cap cuticle, light pinkish-orange on cap flesh; NH4OH = dingy amber to mustard yellow on cap cuticle, negative on cap flesh. The chemical tests on the pileipellis are inconsistent with BRB.

DNA Sequencing Results and Discussion:
> A clean and contiguous TEF-1-alpha sequence of 679 bps was obtained from this collection. There are 7 ambiguous bases: 4 x “Y” (C/T), 2 x “R” (A/G) and 1 x “S” (C/G).
> A BLASTn search of this sequence gave the following relevant top hits:
KF030405: Boletus bicolor var. bicolor voucher MB07-001 = 671/680 = 98.7% similarity; 6/9 mismatches are due to the ambiguous bases, 2 mismatches are editing errors in the EF1-983F primer of KF030405
KF030406: Boletus rufomaculatus voucher 4414 (E. Both’s holotype) = 668/677 = 98.7% similarity; 7/9 mismatches are due to the ambiguous bases, 1 mismatch is an editing error in the EF1-983F primer of KF030406
KF112167: Boletus sp. HKAS 63607 (Baorangia pseudocalopus from China) = 604/621 = 97.3% similarity
KF112167: Boletus sp. HKAS 75081 (Baorangia pseudocalopus from China) = 602/621 = 96.9% similarity
> A GenBank-generated phylogram of the first 27 hits from the BLASTn search was posted to this observation.

Smooth cap, elongated pores. Found high up on what I believe to be is an oak snag.

This weird polypore shingles a tall dead oak sort of like turkey tails on a fallen log. The fungus falls off like leaves or petals in large enough quantities to pile. The flesh is a bit papery but also meaty, and has an earthy smell.

On wood.

White spore print.

results.notes:
I managed to pluck this one before it was colonized by the mold that I’ve seen on almost all the T. rubrobrunneus so far this summer.

KOH turns the purple cap surface yellowish-olive (I’m not quite sure how to describe this color). Color in the photo is accurate.

Sometimes I see a reddish component to the KOH reaction on the cap of rubrobrunneus. But this yellowish-olive reaction is the most common color change.
